awd_titl_txt: Intersystem Crossing Dynamics in Thio-Substituted Pyrimidine Nucleobases Studied by Time-resolved Photoionization Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Ullrich of the University of Georgia is using laser spectroscopy to study the response of modified nucleobases to ultraviolet (UV) irradiation.   Nucleobases are molecular components of DNA, and thus form the building blocks of our genetic coding material.  Naturally occurring nucleobases are known to protect themselves against UV radiation through processes within the nucleobase molecule that dissipate potentially harmful UV energy into heat. However, the details of these processes are not well understood.   Prof. Ullrich is uncovering these details by making slight changes to the nucleobase structure, and observing changes in how UV light is dissipated.   In some cases, for example when an oxygen atom is replaced by a sulfur atom, the nucleobase has difficulty dissipating the energy from the UV light.  This is to say it remains "excited", and therefore vulnerable to damage.  While such a condition may not be desirable for normal strand of DNA, it may be beneficial in cancer treatments, where UV or other light energy may be used to specifically attack cancer cells.

In this project time-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy is applied to the study of pyrimidine thiobases to unravel the mechanistic details governing their unique ultrafast intersystem crossing dynamics. Supplemented by ab-initio calculations and dynamics simulations intricate specifics of the excited state potential energy surfaces such as couplings between the lowest excited states, potential energy barriers, and accessibility of conical intersections are revealed. Particular focus is on the role of low-lying singlet states of n-pi character, given their widespread emergence as the key doorway for accessing the triplet manifold. The project trains undergraduate and graduate students as well as summer interns who participate in the research activities and outcomes of the research are broadly disseminated to the public through science show performances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The canonical nucleobases, which form the building blocks of our genetic coding material, are known to protect themselves against photodamage through ultrafast internal conversion processes that dissipate potentially harmful ultraviolet (UV) energy into heat. However, seemingly minor changes such as single atom substitutions can profoundly alter the photophysics of the nucleobases. In thiobases, where one or two oxygen atoms are replaced by sulfur, these internal conversion pathways are inaccessible and crossing onto the triplet manifold becomes highly efficient. In this project we used time-resolved laser spectroscopy to study the response of thionated pyrimidine nucleobases to UV irradiation and developed a molecular level mechanistic picture of the intersystem crossing dynamics. Overall, our work has shown that all pyrimidine thiobases follow a similar deactivation mechanism that involves internal conversion to the lowest singlet excited state of nπ* character followed by intersystem crossing to a triplet state. However, the photodynamics are surprisingly dependent on the position and degree of thionation, the presence of other substituents (e.g. methyl group), and tautomeric forms. With the help of ab initio calculations and dynamics simulations, we associated the different behaviors with intricate details of the excited state potential energy surfaces such as couplings between the lowest excited states, potential energy barriers, and accessibility of conical intersections.  

The research activities provided extensive training for undergraduate and graduate students in areas including optics, electronics, vacuum technologies and equipment interfacing as well as photochemistry. This award also supported outreach activities such as science shows and demonstrations at public events.  

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2023
Modified by: Susanne Ullrich
